[LEXICON]: Occasionally dense, archaic vocabulary (e.g., "lucubrations," "infancy of art") may impede readability for modern readers.
[SYNTAX]: Extremely long, complex sentence structures (e.g., Chapter I’s opening) require close attention.

[STRUCTURE]: Minor reliance on assumed context (e.g., significance of *The Middle*, character relationships) without explicit clarification.
[TRANSITION]: Subtle shifts between narrative layers (e.g., Corvick’s subplot, Vereker’s novel) may slightly disrupt seamless flow.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures with multiple nested clauses (e.g., "I had caught Vereker’s glance as he spoke...")

[TRANSITION]: Slight abruptness in shifting from the narrator’s internal reflection to Miss Poyle’s sudden question at dinner
